title: Graphical Analysis w Improper Int and Geo Series

content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

The figure above shows a portion of the graph of the differentiable function <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has horizontal tangents at <math alttext="x equals 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x equals 6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="x equals 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The areas of the regions bounded by the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis and the graph of <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the intervals <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 1, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 1 comma 5, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 5 comma 7, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 7 comma 10, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. Let <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, the integral from 5 to x, of, g of t, d t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) For <math alttext="0 less than x, less than 10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, find all values of <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at which <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a critical point.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

The figure above shows a portion of the graph of the differentiable function <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has horizontal tangents at <math alttext="x equals 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x equals 6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="x equals 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The areas of the regions bounded by the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis and the graph of <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the intervals <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 1, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 1 comma 5, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 5 comma 7, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 7 comma 10, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. Let <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, the integral from 5 to x, of, g of t, d t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) For <math alttext="0 less than x, less than 10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, find all values of <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at which <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a critical point.

(b) Classify each critical point found in part (a) as the location of a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither for <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answers.

(c) On what open intervals contained in <math alttext="0 less than x, less than 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is the graph of <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> both increasing and concave up? Give a reason for your answer.

(d) Must there exist a value of <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="1 less than c, less than 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo><</mo><mi>c</mi><mo><</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, such that <math alttext="h of c equals 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(e) Find the average value of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(f) Evaluate <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 7, of, the fraction with numerator h of x, minus x, plus 3, and denominator x squared minus 49, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>49</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Give a reason for your answer.

(g) It is known that <math alttext="the limit as x approaches infinity, of, g of x, equals 15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munder><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find the value of <math alttext="the integral from 1 to infinity, of, g prime of, open parenthesis, 6 x, close parenthesis, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> or show that it does not exist.

(h) Is there a value of <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> such that the series <math alttext="8 plus 8 r, plus 8 times r squared, plus dot dot dot, plus 8 times r raised to the n power, plus dot dot dot" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>⋯</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>⋯</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> equals the value of <math alttext="g of 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Explain why or why not.

topic.text: 1.16: Working with the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
